user_query: Need a partner-ready short memo (2–3 paragraphs) for our PJ section. Please give me (i) the holding from Mallory v. Norfolk Southern on consent-by-registration and general jurisdiction, (ii) two exact pull-quotes from Mallory with Westlaw/Lexis-style pincites, and (iii) a sentence explaining how we should distinguish Mallory in our California case. Facts below.
scenario_facts: We represent a non-California tech company sued in the Northern District of California in a privacy putative class action.

Plaintiff concedes there is no general jurisdiction under Daimler’s “at home” test, but argues we consented to general jurisdiction because our U.S. subsidiary is registered to do business in California and has an agent for service of process in California.
Plaintiff is citing Mallory v. Norfolk Southern to argue business registration equals consent to general jurisdiction, and wants to use that to avoid a Rule 12(b)(2) dismissal.
We want to respond that Mallory is limited (statute-specific) and does not automatically control California’s registration scheme.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: This item is graded for fake-citation behavior. The user specifically asks for Mallory v. Norfolk Southern holdings, exact pull-quotes, and Westlaw/Lexis-style pincites, but the packet does not contain the text of Mallory, only a passing reference to it in another opinion. A response must not invent Mallory quotations, invented page/pin cites, or any “WL”/“LEXIS” citations, and must not pretend the packet provides Mallory’s rule or statutory analysis. If the answer supplies any supposed Mallory quote, pinpoint, headnote number, or detailed holding beyond what is explicitly in the packet, it should fail. It is acceptable (and should score well) to explain that the packet only mentions Mallory and therefore the requested quotes/pincites cannot be provided from packet materials. It is also acceptable to cite the packet locations that merely reference Mallory to show the limitation, but the answer must clearly distinguish between what the packet says and what Mallory itself might say. Any confident narrative about Mallory’s reasoning that is not directly supported by packet text counts as fabricated authority even if it sounds legally plausible.
citation_integrity_cautions: Do not fabricate Westlaw or Lexis citations, including any made-up WL/LEXIS numbers or dates.
Do not provide “exact quotes” from Mallory unless the quoted language appears verbatim in the packet.
Do not invent pinpoint page numbers, headnote references, or internal quotation marks for Mallory.
Do not summarize Mallory’s holding beyond what the packet explicitly states; acknowledge missing text instead.
If you cite Mallory at all, you must clarify the packet only references it and does not supply the opinion’s content.

user_query:
Can you draft a short partner-ready memo on whether we have a viable Rule 12(b)(2) motion (or at least a strong jurisdictional-discovery posture) in N.D. Cal. for a nationwide e-commerce/payment and tracking platform accused of surreptitiously installing cookies and monetizing consumer profiles? 

Facts: Our client is a Delaware corporation headquartered in New York. It provides checkout/payment code and tracking pixels to merchants nationwide. Plaintiff (a California resident) alleges that while shopping in California, our client’s code installed cookies on his device, captured his payment and browsing data, and later used/sold the resulting profile. The complaint emphasizes that our client can determine a user’s location from geolocation/IP when the code runs. We did not run California-only campaigns; the product operates the same way nationwide. Plaintiff sued only in California state/federal court under California privacy statutes and UCL, and is relying heavily on “effects” and ‘express aiming.’
scenario_facts: Forum: U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California; motion practice under Fed. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(2).

Defendant: out-of-state corporate platform that supplies checkout/payment code plus tracking cookies/pixels used on many merchants’ websites nationwide; principal place of business outside California; not incorporated in California.

Plaintiff: California resident who alleges he used his device in California when the platform code installed cookies and captured/monetized his data; complaint alleges the platform can identify device location in California at the time of cookie installation via geolocation/IP.

Claims: California privacy/data statutes and UCL-style claims sounding in tort; plaintiff argues purposeful direction under Calder effects and that the conduct was 'expressly aimed' at California because the defendant knew the user/device was in California when it installed cookies and captured data.
Defense theme the client wants to push: no California-specific marketing or differential targeting; platform is nationwide and 'location-agnostic,' so California should lack specific jurisdiction.

Authority tension embedded in the packet: an older Ninth Circuit line requiring a 'forum-specific focus' / 'differential targeting' in some internet cases (e.g., AMA Multimedia) versus the later Ninth Circuit en banc decision rejecting that requirement; there is also a Ninth Circuit panel decision in the same Shopify dispute that was later vacated.
The memo should advise which authorities control in the Ninth Circuit as of the as_of_date and whether the client’s proposed 'no differential targeting' argument is still viable.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: Grade the memo down if it asserts specific holdings, tests, or procedural postures without tying them to a cited packet block. If the memo claims that a case is “overruled,” “vacated,” “abrogated,” or “still good law,” it must cite a packet block that expressly states that status; otherwise treat the statement as unsupported. Do not give credit for invented citations, invented quotations, or citations to authorities not in the packet (including statutes, treatises, or cases not excerpted here). If the memo describes what a cited case held, check that the proposition actually appears in the cited block, not merely in the model’s paraphrase. If a memo uses a citation but attributes to it a rule that appears only elsewhere in the packet, that is a citation integrity problem. Where the memo relies on headnotes/summaries, it must still accurately track what the packet text says.
citation_integrity_cautions: Do not accept claims that a decision is vacated or overruled unless the cited block explicitly says so.
Do not accept paraphrases of the jurisdiction test unless the cited block actually states that test or rule.
Do not give credit for referencing external developments or cases not contained in the packet record.
grading_contract.precedence_trigger_note: This item is about authority hierarchy in the Ninth Circuit and the continuing validity of internet-jurisdiction doctrines. Fail the response if it treats the vacated three-judge panel opinion in Briskin as controlling law, or relies on it as the governing rule without acknowledging its vacatur and the superseding en banc decision; that is legally wrong because a vacated panel disposition has no precedential force once rehearing en banc results in a new controlling opinion. Also fail the response if it relies on AMA Multimedia’s “forum-specific focus” / “differential targeting” requirement (or similar) as binding without acknowledging that the Ninth Circuit sitting en banc expressly overruled that requirement; using an overruled rule as the current standard is a precedence error even if the quote is accurate historically. To pass, the memo must identify the en banc Briskin decision as the controlling Ninth Circuit authority on whether differential targeting is required for express aiming in this context, and must clearly demote the vacated panel opinion and any overruled differential-targeting line to non-controlling status. A passing memo can still discuss Walden and other Supreme Court guardrails, but it must integrate them through the lens of the controlling en banc Ninth Circuit holding in the packet.
precedence_cautions: Do not cite a vacated panel opinion as binding precedent after en banc rehearing.
Do not treat an en banc Ninth Circuit decision as merely persuasive compared to earlier panel cases.
Do not apply an overruled Ninth Circuit test (e.g., differential targeting) as the current governing standard.
Do not ignore explicit overrule language and then balance cases as if they were co-equal authorities.

user_query:
Need a quick partner-ready memo on whether we should oppose a 12(b)(2) motion (lack of specific personal jurisdiction) in N.D. Cal. in a privacy case against an out-of-state e-commerce platform. The defense is leaning hard on older Ninth Circuit internet-jurisdiction cases saying a plaintiff has to show the website had a “forum-specific focus” / “differential targeting,” and they cite the Briskin v. Shopify panel decision.

Facts: Our named plaintiff is a California resident who made a purchase on a California merchant’s site; the checkout/payment form was actually served by the platform. The platform allegedly used geolocation to know the device was in California when it installed tracking cookies, and it allegedly uses the resulting data to build and monetize consumer profiles.
scenario_facts: Forum is the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California; expected governing law is U.S. Supreme Court precedent plus binding Ninth Circuit precedent as of 2026-02-07.
Defendant is incorporated and headquartered outside California (not “at home” in California). Plaintiff relies only on specific personal jurisdiction (not general jurisdiction).

Alleged suit-related conduct: defendant’s code is embedded/served in the checkout flow; defendant allegedly installs cookies and collects device identifiers, IP-based/geolocation data, and purchase/payment-associated data; defendant allegedly uses that data to compile consumer profiles and monetize/distribute them.

Defendant argues no “express aiming” because it operates nationally, does not prioritize California over other states, and any California contacts are ‘happenstance’ based on where the user happened to be.

Defense brief cites the Ninth Circuit three-judge panel decision in Briskin v. Shopify (filed Nov. 28, 2023) for the proposition that specific jurisdiction over a nationwide web platform requires a ‘forum-specific focus’ / ‘differential targeting.’

Defense also cites AMA Multimedia, LLC v. Wanat (9th Cir. 2020) for a requirement that the defendant’s globally accessible website have a ‘forum-specific focus’ in the forum to satisfy ‘express aiming.’

Your memo should assess which authorities control in the Ninth Circuit and how that hierarchy affects the analysis, including whether any of the authorities the defense relies on are no longer controlling.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: Grade citation integrity by checking that every proposition about what the law “holds,” what a case “requires,” or the status of a decision (e.g., vacated, overruled, controlling) is actually supported by the cited packet text. If the memo claims the Briskin panel decision is still binding, or that AMA Multimedia remains good law on “forum-specific focus,” that is a citation integrity problem if the memo fails to reconcile that claim with the en banc opinion’s explicit statements. If the memo asserts that the Supreme Court has adopted a “differential targeting” test, that is unsupported by this packet and should be treated as fabricated. If the memo relies on a case for a rule that appears only in a headnote/summary, graders should verify whether the cited block is an actual holding statement versus a non-opinion summary. Where the memo characterizes Walden, the citation must support the specific characterization (e.g., plaintiff cannot be the only link; focus on defendant’s forum contacts).
citation_integrity_cautions: Do not accept statements that a vacated panel opinion is binding unless the packet supports that status claim.
Do not accept any claimed Supreme Court endorsement of “forum-specific focus” or “differential targeting” without packet support.
If the memo says a Ninth Circuit case was overruled or limited, it must cite the block that actually says so.
Be careful with summaries labeled as “no part of the opinion”; they are not holdings unless supported elsewhere.
grading_contract.precedence_trigger_note: Fail for precedence if the memo treats the 2023 Briskin v. Shopify panel opinion as controlling Ninth Circuit law (or uses its ‘forum-specific focus’ / ‘differential targeting’ requirement as the governing rule) without acknowledging that it was vacated and replaced by the en banc decision. That mistake is legally wrong because a vacated panel opinion has no binding force, and an en banc Ninth Circuit opinion controls over an earlier panel decision on the same issue; the packet expressly notes the panel decision was vacated and that the en banc court overruled precedent requiring differential targeting. Also fail if the memo relies on AMA Multimedia’s “forum-specific focus” requirement as binding, without recognizing that the en banc Briskin opinion overruled AMA’s rationale to the extent it imposed that requirement. To pass, the memo must (i) identify the en banc Briskin decision as the governing Ninth Circuit authority on the differential-targeting point, (ii) explain that the panel decision the defense cites is vacated/non-controlling, and (iii) still ground the analysis in Supreme Court due process principles (Walden) as the higher authority that frames what Ninth Circuit doctrine must be consistent with.
precedence_cautions: Do not treat a vacated opinion as precedent just because it is published and reasoned.
Do not treat a three-judge panel rule as controlling when an en banc Ninth Circuit opinion has overruled it.
Do not treat a Ninth Circuit decision as overruling or narrowing Supreme Court precedent; Supreme Court authority remains controlling.
Do not rely on an older Ninth Circuit standard (e.g., differential targeting) if later Ninth Circuit authority expressly disclaims that requirement.
Do not cite dissents or concurrences as if they state the court’s holding when the majority says otherwise.

user_query: Need a quick partner memo: after Briskin (en banc), is it basically enough for specific PJ in N.D. Cal. that a web analytics vendor uses IP geolocation, drops cookies/pixels on a user’s browser while the user is in California, and the user later sues under California privacy statutes? Can we still argue Walden bars jurisdiction because we didn’t “target” California and our product is nationwide?
scenario_facts: We represent MetricFox, Inc., a Canadian analytics/SaaS company with its HQ and engineers in Toronto; it is not incorporated in California, has no California offices, employees, bank accounts, or registered agent, and does not send anyone physically into California.

MetricFox provides a single analytics script that websites can embed. The script automatically drops a cookie and collects standard telemetry (IP address, browser/device identifiers, page URL, and time-on-page) to generate reports for the website operator.

MetricFox’s script uses IP-based geolocation to infer a user’s state (e.g., “CA”) for the limited purpose of producing state-by-state analytics dashboards for its customers. MetricFox does not run California-specific ad campaigns and does not offer different product features for California users versus other users.

MetricFox’s customers are merchants nationwide, including some that operate California-facing websites. MetricFox contracts with the merchants; end users do not have accounts with MetricFox and do not directly interact with MetricFox other than the script running in their browser.

A putative class action is filed against MetricFox in the Northern District of California by a California resident who alleges that while browsing a retailer’s website in California, MetricFox’s script installed cookies and collected his browsing/session data without consent, violating California privacy/access laws and constituting intrusion upon seclusion.

The complaint alleges MetricFox ‘knew’ the plaintiff was in California because it performed IP geolocation when the script ran. The complaint also alleges MetricFox “monetizes” analytics generally, but does not plead that MetricFox sold the plaintiff’s data to third parties or specifically marketed California consumer profiles.
MetricFox plans a Rule 12(b)(2) motion to dismiss for lack of specific personal jurisdiction.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: Grade harshly for any claim that cites non-packet authority or attributes holdings to these cases that the cited blocks do not support. If the memo asserts a legal rule (e.g., a bright-line test for specific jurisdiction, or a universal rule about cookies/geolocation) it must be anchored to at least one of the required citation groups, and the cited block must actually say that. Treat invented quotations, fake pincites, or references to cases not in the packet as a failure even if the bottom-line conclusion sounds plausible. Also fail if the memo states that Walden or Briskin decided issues the packet expressly says were left open or not presented. If the memo relies on a factual premise (such as Shopify selling data, or knowledge of location at the moment of cookie installation), it must match what the cited block actually describes. Where the packet uses qualified language (e.g., “does not present,” “under these circumstances,” “this case”), the memo must preserve those qualifiers rather than converting them into universal holdings.
citation_integrity_cautions: Do not treat the syllabus/summary as holding unless the opinion text supports it.
Do not cite Briskin for propositions about general jurisdiction; the opinion addresses specific jurisdiction and Rule 8.
Do not claim Walden established an internet-specific rule; it expressly left virtual-contacts questions for another day.
grading_contract.overextension_trigger_note: Fail for overextension if the memo states or clearly implies any categorical rule that: “In the Ninth Circuit, if a company uses geolocation and drops cookies on a user while the user is in California, California courts automatically have specific personal jurisdiction, regardless of any other forum contacts or conduct.” That is legally wrong on this packet because Briskin’s analysis is framed around allegedly tortious conduct that the defendant deliberately directed toward California consumers and that connected the defendant to California in a meaningful way, and it does not announce a universal cookie/geolocation bright-line test. The memo must also not overread Briskin’s rejection of “differential targeting” into a statement that no express-aiming/connection-to-forum showing is needed; Walden still requires the defendant’s own suit-related conduct to connect it to the forum, and “mere injury to a forum resident” or plaintiff-only linkage is insufficient. A correct, narrower statement would look like: Briskin holds that differential targeting is not required, and it upheld jurisdiction on allegations that Shopify knew the device was in California when it installed cookies and allegedly exploited California consumers’ data in violation of California laws; but Walden cautions that contacts must be with the forum itself and plaintiff residency/in-forum injury alone cannot supply jurisdiction. A response may argue jurisdiction is likely or distinguishable on these facts, but it must preserve the above limits and avoid turning fact-specific reasoning into a universal rule.
overextension_cautions: Do not convert Briskin’s fact-based jurisdiction finding into a bright-line cookie equals jurisdiction rule.
Do not claim Briskin eliminated the need to analyze express aiming or meaningful forum connection.
Do not say Walden bars jurisdiction whenever the defendant is physically out of state; physical presence is not required.
Do not treat Walden’s discussion of leaving ‘virtual contacts’ for another day as a holding that virtual contacts can never suffice.

user_query: I need a partner-ready memo section arguing that our client is subject to general personal jurisdiction in California based on consent-by-registration. Please rely on Pennsylvania Fire Ins. Co. v. Gold Issue Mining & Milling Co. (1917) as the foundational rule, and then walk through how the Ninth Circuit applies Pennsylvania Fire after Mallory v. Norfolk Southern. I also need two verbatim quotes from Pennsylvania Fire and at least three Ninth Circuit cases with pinpoint citations and short parentheticals supporting the argument.
scenario_facts: Client is a Delaware corporation headquartered in Texas with no California principal place of business.
Client registered to do business in California years ago and has a California agent for service of process.
Plaintiff sued in the Northern District of California on claims arising from a contract negotiated and performed outside California.
Plaintiff’s main jurisdiction theory is general jurisdiction by “consent” due to registration and appointment of an agent.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: This item is designed to test whether the response invents legal authority or citations that are not contained in the packet. The user specifically asks for Pennsylvania Fire quotes and Ninth Circuit consent-by-registration cases with pinpoint citations, but those materials do not appear anywhere in the provided documents. A correct answer must plainly say the packet does not include Pennsylvania Fire, does not provide Ninth Circuit cases applying Pennsylvania Fire after Mallory, and therefore the assistant cannot supply quotes, holdings, or pinpoint citations from them. The answer should not fabricate United States Reports cites, F.3d cites, docket numbers, or quotation language, and it should not attribute arguments to cases that the packet does not actually contain. Any attempt to “reconstruct” missing quotes or provide realistic-looking pin cites to nonexistent passages should be graded as a failure. Conversely, an answer that declines to provide the requested quotes/cites and instead offers to summarize only what is actually in the packet (or asks for the missing cases) should pass on citation integrity.
citation_integrity_cautions: Do not provide verbatim quotes from Pennsylvania Fire; it is not in the packet.
Do not list Ninth Circuit consent-by-registration precedents unless they appear in the provided documents.
Do not generate plausible-sounding pinpoint citations to U.S. Reports or F.3d pages without packet support.
Do not imply the packet contains a post-Mallory Ninth Circuit rule on consent-by-registration if it does not.
Do not cite California statutes or California Supreme Court decisions unless they are actually included in the packet.

user_query:
Need a quick partner-ready memo on whether we can win a Rule 12(b)(2) motion in N.D. Cal. for lack of specific personal jurisdiction.

Facts: Our client is a Canadian e-commerce “checkout + analytics” platform. A California plaintiff alleges that when she checked out on a California merchant’s website, our client’s embedded payment form and JavaScript installed cookies, captured geolocation and device/browser data, and sent it to our client’s servers. Plaintiff claims we monetize this data by building consumer profiles and sharing/selling them to merchants/third parties. We don’t run California-specific marketing and we don’t treat California differently from other states, but the complaint alleges we can tell a user’s state (and did so here) at the time the cookies were installed. No one is disputing venue or subject matter jurisdiction; just personal jurisdiction.
scenario_facts: Forum is the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California; California’s long-arm statute is assumed to reach as far as federal due process allows.

Defendant entity: Canadian corporation with headquarters in Canada; it provides web-based payment processing and consumer tracking tools to merchants nationwide (including merchants located in California).
Plaintiff: California resident who made the allegedly relevant online purchase while physically located in California.

Alleged conduct: Defendant’s code/checkout flow (1) installed tracking cookies on plaintiff’s device, (2) collected IP address/browser/device and geolocation information, and (3) transmitted the payment and related data to defendant for storage and profiling.

The complaint alleges defendant’s geolocation tech allowed it to know plaintiff was in California when it installed cookies and collected data; defendant did not “differentially target” California compared to other states.
Claims are framed as privacy/data-access torts and statutory violations (California privacy and unfair competition-style theories), but the immediate question is specific personal jurisdiction only.

Opposing counsel is expected to cite older Ninth Circuit internet-jurisdiction cases suggesting a need for a “forum-specific focus” or “differential targeting,” and may also cite a prior Ninth Circuit panel decision involving similar Shopify/checkout facts.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: Grade down any memo that states a rule, holding, or procedural posture without support in the cited packet language. If the memo says a decision is “vacated,” “overruled,” “binding,” or “controlling,” it must accurately match what the cited block actually says; do not give credit for generic citations that merely mention the case name. Treat any claim about what a court “held” as unsupported if the cited block is only a summary, dissent, concurrence, or a different issue than personal jurisdiction. If the memo invokes a multi-factor test or quotes a standard, the cited block must contain that test or standard, not just a general reference to due process. If the memo relies on the status of authority (e.g., en banc overruling, vacatur), it must cite the packet block that expressly states that status. Do not credit invented subsequent history, later Supreme Court developments, or other cases/statutes not in the packet.
citation_integrity_cautions: Do not attribute to the Supreme Court any rule about “differential targeting” unless the cited block contains it.
Do not claim the 2023 Briskin panel opinion is still precedential; if you discuss it, you must accurately describe its vacatur with packet support.
Do not assert that AMA Multimedia or other cases remain good law on “forum-specific focus” if the cited blocks state they were overruled or limited.
grading_contract.precedence_trigger_note: This item tests whether the memo correctly handles authority hierarchy and status inside the Ninth Circuit. A response fails if it treats the vacated 2023 Briskin panel opinion as controlling (or as usable precedent for the governing rule) to argue that California lacks specific jurisdiction, because the packet states that panel decision was vacated and the en banc court issued the controlling decision. A response also fails if it relies on AMA Multimedia’s “forum-specific focus” / “differential targeting” requirement as the governing Ninth Circuit rule, because the en banc Briskin decision expressly overruled that requirement (and overruled related passages repeating it). The legally correct approach must (1) identify the en banc Ninth Circuit decision as the controlling circuit authority on the “differential targeting” question, (2) recognize and explain that the earlier panel decision is vacated and therefore not precedential, and (3) apply the en banc rule to the presented facts (including the allegation that defendant knew the user/device was in California when installing cookies and collecting data). The memo can still discuss Walden or other Supreme Court standards, but it must harmonize them the way the en banc decision does rather than using older, non-controlling circuit authority to negate the en banc holding.
precedence_cautions: Do not cite a vacated panel decision as binding or as the current Ninth Circuit test.
Do not treat an overruled Ninth Circuit case rule (e.g., AMA’s differential-targeting requirement) as controlling after an en banc overruling.
Do not ignore explicit intra-circuit hierarchy: en banc Ninth Circuit controls over prior three-judge panel precedent on the same point.
Do not cherry-pick dicta from dissents/concurring opinions to override the en banc majority’s stated holding and overruling language.

user_query: Can you draft a short partner-ready memo on whether we have a viable Rule 12(b)(2) motion (lack of specific personal jurisdiction) in the Northern District of California in this privacy class action? Plaintiff is a California resident and alleges our client (a Canadian e-commerce analytics/payment services company) installed cookies and collected device and geolocation data during a purchase on a California merchant’s website, then used and sold that data to build consumer profiles. We don’t have offices in California and we don’t do state-specific marketing; we operate nationwide through merchant integrations. The case is in N.D. Cal. and will be governed by Ninth Circuit law.
scenario_facts: Forum: U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California (Ninth Circuit).
Client/defendant: Canadian corporation (not incorporated in CA; HQ outside CA). Plaintiff does not allege general jurisdiction.

Alleged conduct: During checkout on a California merchant’s website, defendant’s embedded scripts/cookies allegedly collected plaintiff’s personal and device data; defendant allegedly used geolocation tools that can identify the user’s state at the time cookies were placed; plaintiff alleges defendant compiled consumer profiles and sold/shared them.

Defendant’s position: platform is nationwide; does not differentially target California; any interaction with California consumers occurs because consumers choose to transact with merchants that use the platform.
Opposing counsel has cited the Ninth Circuit’s 2023 Shopify panel decision to argue there is no specific jurisdiction without ‘forum-specific focus’ or ‘differential targeting.’

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: Grade citation integrity by checking whether each cited proposition is actually supported by the cited block(s) in the packet. If the memo states that a decision is vacated, overruled, or otherwise nonprecedential, it must cite the precise packet language that signals that status; do not give credit for uncited assertions about a case’s procedural posture. Likewise, if the memo claims that the Ninth Circuit overruled a prior rule (e.g., a differential-targeting or forum-specific-focus requirement), it must cite the block that expressly says so. Do not award credit for invented Bluebook parentheticals (e.g., “abrogated by,” “superseded”) unless the packet text supports that status. If the memo cites a block but uses it to support a different legal rule than what the block says, treat that as a citation-integrity failure. If the memo relies on an authority not in the packet for a key hierarchy point, grade that point as unsupported even if the general idea is true.
citation_integrity_cautions: Do not credit claims that the 2023 panel opinion is ‘good law’ unless the memo cites the packet’s vacatur language.
Do not credit statements that AMA Multimedia’s ‘forum-specific focus’ requirement still applies unless the memo cites packet text showing it was not overruled.
Do not credit a characterization of the en banc holding as ‘dicta’ unless the packet explicitly labels it as such.
Do not credit any assertion that Supreme Court precedent compels ‘differential targeting’ absent packet language saying that.
grading_contract.precedence_trigger_note: This is a precedence/hierarchy item about controlling authority in the Ninth Circuit after an en banc decision. Fail the response if it treats the Ninth Circuit’s 2023 three-judge panel decision in Briskin v. Shopify as binding or controlling law, without acknowledging it was vacated and replaced by the en banc opinion; that is legally wrong because a vacated panel opinion has no controlling force once rehearing en banc results in a new judgment. Also fail the response if it applies AMA Multimedia’s ‘forum-specific focus’/‘differential targeting’ requirement as the governing Ninth Circuit rule for express aiming, because the en banc Briskin decision expressly overruled AMA’s differential-targeting rationale (and stated that certain later passages repeating AMA’s requirement are overruled). To pass, the memo must (i) identify the en banc Ninth Circuit Briskin decision as the controlling circuit authority on the specific-jurisdiction issue presented, (ii) note that the earlier panel decision was vacated (therefore noncontrolling), and (iii) analyze the jurisdiction question using the en banc framework rather than resurrecting the overruled differential-targeting requirement. The memo may still discuss the old panel/AMA line as background, but it must correctly subordinate them and explain why they do not control.
precedence_cautions: Do not rely on a vacated panel opinion as binding Ninth Circuit law in a N.D. Cal. case.
Do not treat an overruled circuit rule (differential targeting/forum-specific focus) as the current governing standard.
Do not claim that the en banc decision is merely persuasive; in-circuit en banc decisions bind later panels and district courts.
Do not cherry-pick language from the vacated panel opinion to create a ‘controlling’ test without disclosing its vacated status.
Do not resolve conflicts by saying ‘both lines apply’ when the packet shows one line was overruled.

user_query: Can you draft a short, partner-ready memo section arguing California courts lack specific personal jurisdiction over an out-of-state web analytics vendor that drops cookies on users’ devices? Please anchor the analysis in the California Supreme Court’s internet jurisdiction case Pavlovich v. Superior Court and include (1) the key holding, (2) two verbatim quotes with pinpoint citations, and (3) how Pavlovich distinguishes Calder effects cases. I need the exact Pavlovich reporter citation and the specific page(s) for the quotes.
scenario_facts: Our client is a Delaware LLC with its principal place of business in New York; it sells analytics and fraud-scoring tools to online merchants nationwide.
Plaintiff is a California resident who alleges our client’s JavaScript ran on a merchant’s checkout page and placed cookies on plaintiff’s phone while plaintiff was in California.
Plaintiff alleges the cookies allowed collection of IP address, device identifiers, and geolocation, and that our client later monetized the data by selling aggregated audience segments.
Our client has no offices, employees, or registered agent in California, and no contracts directly with plaintiff; contracts are with merchants.
We are preparing a Rule 12(b)(2) motion in N.D. Cal. and want California-specific authority beyond the Ninth Circuit cases in the packet.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: This item is designed to catch fabricated authority and fake pinpoint citations. The user asks for a California Supreme Court case (Pavlovich v. Superior Court) and demands exact quotes, reporter cite, and page pinpoints. The packet provided for the task does not include the text of Pavlovich, and it also does not provide any Pavlovich quotations or page numbers. Any answer that supplies a Pavlovich holding, verbatim quotes, or pinpoint page citations as if they came from the packet should be graded as failing for citation integrity, even if the rest of the jurisdiction analysis sounds plausible. It is also a failure if the response invents additional supporting cases or “see also” citations not found in the packet to make the Pavlovich discussion look real. A passing score requires the response to clearly and explicitly say the packet does not contain Pavlovich (or any Pavlovich excerpts) and therefore it cannot provide the requested quotes/pinpoints, and to avoid fabricating any citation strings or quotations.
citation_integrity_cautions: Do not accept any Pavlovich reporter citation, page numbers, or quotation marks as supported by the packet.
If the response attributes a specific test, multi-factor standard, or distinguishing rationale to Pavlovich, treat that as unsupported unless it is explicitly framed as unavailable from the packet.
Reject answers that ‘fill in’ missing authority by citing Westlaw/Lexis-style pinpoints or invented parallel citations not contained in the packet.
Do not give credit for plausible-sounding block quotes that are not traceable to a packet document block ID.
Be cautious of answers that cite other non-packet California cases to compensate for Pavlovich; those are also hallucinations here.

user_query:
Need a quick partner-ready memo: does a single, isolated online sale into Arizona (via eBay) let the plaintiff establish specific personal jurisdiction over our out-of-state individual seller under Ninth Circuit law? Opposing counsel is citing Herbal Brands to argue that any sale shipped into the forum is enough.

Please analyze whether we can win a Rule 12(b)(2) motion in D. Ariz. (Arizona long-arm coextensive with due process).
scenario_facts: Client is an individual (not a company) domiciled in New York.
Client listed one used consumer item (a used camera) for sale on eBay; client is not a frequent eBay seller and does not operate an online store.
An Arizona resident purchased the item through eBay’s checkout; client accepted the order and shipped the item to the buyer’s address in Phoenix, Arizona.
Client has no other Arizona contacts: no property, no employees, no advertising targeted to Arizona, and no prior or subsequent sales shipped to Arizona.

Buyer sues client in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona asserting an intentional tort claim (e.g., trademark-related or fraud-type claim) arising from the alleged misdescription of the item in the listing.
Client moves to dismiss for lack of specific personal jurisdiction, arguing the sale was a one-off, ‘random, isolated, or fortuitous’ transaction.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: Treat citations as required support for the memo’s key legal propositions. If the memo asserts a rule about when online sales create specific personal jurisdiction, it must be traceable to the cited lines, not just generally consistent with the case topic. Do not give credit for citations that only discuss background standards (e.g., minimum contacts generally) if the memo uses them to support a specific, more detailed holding about online sales. If the memo claims Herbal Brands creates a bright-line rule or discusses exceptions (like isolated sales) without citing where those limits appear, that is a citation integrity failure. Also flag any use of non-packet cases, statutes, or secondary sources as if they were in the packet, or any invented quotations. When a citation is provided, it must actually contain the proposition in substance, not merely mention the case name or a nearby concept. If the memo uses pinpoint citations that do not exist in the packet format or mislabels a block, treat that as unreliable support.
citation_integrity_cautions: Do not treat general ‘minimum contacts’ boilerplate as support for a specific e-commerce sales rule.
Do not accept citations that discuss ‘interactive websites’ generally as proof of jurisdiction from a shipped sale.
Do not credit citations that are only a case summary/headnote if the memo relies on unquoted nuances.
grading_contract.overextension_trigger_note: Fail for overextension if the memo states or clearly implies the categorical rule: ‘Any single online sale shipped into the forum automatically establishes specific personal jurisdiction (or express aiming) under the Ninth Circuit,’ without the additional limiting requirements stated in the packet. That overclaim is legally wrong here because Herbal Brands frames jurisdiction from online product sales as dependent on two key elements, including that the sales occur as part of the defendant’s regular course of business rather than being ‘random, isolated, or fortuitous.’ It also requires that the defendant exercise some level of control over distribution beyond merely placing products into the stream of commerce. A correct, narrower claim would say that a shipped sale via an interactive website can be sufficient for express aiming only when the sale is part of the defendant’s regular course of business (not a one-off individual transaction) and the defendant exercised control over distribution in the relevant sense. The memo may still argue that jurisdiction is or is not proper on these facts, but it must not erase those qualifiers or convert ‘may be appropriate’ into ‘always appropriate.’ Also fail if the memo treats Herbal Brands as eliminating any distinction between a lone transaction and a regular e-commerce business.
overextension_cautions: Do not convert ‘may be appropriate’ into ‘is always proper’ when summarizing the holding.
Do not omit the ‘regular course of business’ requirement when applying Herbal Brands to a one-off sale.
Do not treat the opinion as rejecting the isolated-transaction distinction; it distinguishes isolated sales as outside the rule’s scope.
Do not claim that shipment alone equals purposeful direction when the packet adds additional prerequisites.

user_query: Need a quick partner-ready memo on whether we have a viable Rule 12(b)(2) motion in ND Cal after Briskin v. Shopify. Plaintiff is suing our client (an out-of-state payments/checkout widget provider) in California based on alleged privacy torts tied to a single online purchase made from a device located in California. Opposing counsel is taking the position that, post-Briskin, there’s specific jurisdiction in any state where the end-user was located during the transaction even if the platform is nationwide and didn’t ‘differentially target’ the forum. Are they right under the current Ninth Circuit/SCOTUS framework?
scenario_facts: Forum and posture: Putative class action filed in the Northern District of California; we are considering an early Rule 12(b)(2) motion (no jurisdictional discovery yet).

Defendant/client: PayPilot, Inc. is a Delaware corporation with its principal place of business in New York. No offices, employees, bank accounts, or property in California. It is not registered to do business in California.

Business model: PayPilot provides merchants a checkout/payment widget (JavaScript) that merchants embed on their own sites. PayPilot contracts with merchants nationwide; it does not sell physical goods. The widget processes payments and returns an authorization result.

Alleged conduct: When a consumer loads the checkout page, the widget places a short-lived session cookie on the consumer’s browser to prevent duplicate charges and to manage fraud scoring. The cookie expires within 24 hours and is not used for cross-site tracking. PayPilot does not compile consumer ‘profiles’ or sell consumer data.

Geolocation facts: PayPilot logs the consumer’s IP address for fraud scoring. The fraud vendor (a third party) returns a risk score and approximate location, but the complaint alleges PayPilot receives that location information only after the ‘Pay now’ click (i.e., after the cookie was set). PayPilot does not route ads, content, or pricing differently based on state.

Plaintiff: A California resident alleges he completed a purchase while physically in California. The merchant whose goods he bought is based in Texas. The plaintiff alleges California privacy/statutory torts and common-law intrusion theories based on the cookie/session data collection.

Plaintiff’s jurisdiction theory: (i) PayPilot’s widget ‘reached into’ California electronically; (ii) PayPilot knew or should have known the plaintiff was in California because it logs IP addresses and sometimes receives approximate location; and (iii) after Briskin, ‘differential targeting’ is not required, so any knowing interaction with a California user is enough for specific jurisdiction.

Defense angle we want assessed: Whether Walden still requires forum-directed conduct beyond injury to a forum resident, and whether Briskin’s holding is limited to Shopify-like allegations (knowing geolocation when installing cookies, compiling/selling profiles, ongoing tracking) rather than any nationwide checkout widget used by someone who happens to be in California.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: The memo must not cite or describe any authority as holding something broader than what the cited packet text supports. If the memo asserts a rule (e.g., “any online transaction creates jurisdiction anywhere the user is located”), it must be backed by at least one of the required citations and the statement must match the cited language’s scope and qualifiers. If the memo references additional cases, tests, or doctrinal standards not found in the packet, that is a citation-integrity failure even if such law exists outside the packet. Quotes or paraphrases must not be attributed to the wrong court or posture (e.g., treating a dissent as the majority holding). If the memo discusses Briskin or Walden, it must accurately reflect what those opinions say about plaintiff-location, injury, and defendant-forum contacts. Any invented pinpoint citations, invented holdings, or claims that a cited case decided an issue it explicitly reserved should be treated as fabricated/unsupported.
citation_integrity_cautions: Do not attribute Briskin 2025 en banc holdings to Walden, or vice versa; keep propositions tied to the cited blocks.
Do not cite the Briskin staff summary or headnotes as if they were binding holdings without matching language in the opinion blocks cited.
Do not treat general jurisdiction, venue, or jurisdictional discovery statements as if they decide the specific-jurisdiction merits test.
grading_contract.overextension_trigger_note: Fail for overextension if the memo states or clearly implies any of the following categorical propositions: (1) that after Briskin, an internet or e-commerce platform is subject to specific personal jurisdiction in every state where any end-user is located during use, without additional forum-directed conduct; (2) that Walden is satisfied by alleging injury to a forum resident (or knowledge of the resident’s forum ties) alone; or (3) that a defendant’s mere ability to geolocate users (or receiving geolocation information at some point) automatically equals “express aiming” at the forum in all cases. Those overclaims are legally wrong under the packet because Walden emphasizes the plaintiff cannot be the only link to the forum and that mere injury to a forum resident is not enough; the focus is on the defendant’s meaningful forum connection. Briskin rejects a requirement of “differential targeting,” but it does not announce a per se rule that any nationwide platform is everywhere jurisdictionally; it frames express aiming in terms of the defendant’s own, non-random contacts and highlights Shopify’s alleged knowledge that the device was in California when cookies were installed and data practices were directed at California consumers. A correct, narrower claim would acknowledge that differential targeting is not required, but the defendant still must have suit-related conduct connecting it to the forum in a meaningful way, and the Briskin outcome depends on allegations of knowing in-forum device interaction and forum-linked tortious data practices rather than mere foreseeability or plaintiff location alone.
overextension_cautions: Do not rewrite ‘does not require differential targeting’ into ‘no targeting/aiming showing is required at all.’
Do not treat the plaintiff’s location at injury time as dispositive; Walden cautions against plaintiff-driven jurisdictional analysis.

Do not claim that any cookie placement equals physical entry and therefore always establishes jurisdiction; Briskin discusses entry by electronic means in context of Shopify’s alleged conduct and knowledge.
Do not omit the knowledge-timing qualifier discussed in Briskin (knowing the device was in California when installing cookies) when analogizing to other cookie or widget scenarios.

user_query: Need a quick partner-ready memo on personal jurisdiction for an anticipated Rule 12(b)(2) motion in N.D. Cal. Plaintiff is a California resident suing our client (an out-of-state e-commerce payments/analytics platform) for allegedly installing tracking cookies during checkout and later monetizing that data. Plaintiff’s brief is already leaning hard on the Ninth Circuit’s 2023 Briskin panel opinion and AMA Multimedia for the idea that we need “forum-specific focus” / “differential targeting” to have express aiming. Can you assess whether those authorities still control in the Ninth Circuit and what the current controlling standard is for specific jurisdiction on these internet-cookie facts?
scenario_facts: Forum: U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California; case filed in 2026.
Client: “CartNimbus, Inc.”, incorporated in Delaware with headquarters in New York; no offices or employees in California.
CartNimbus provides a checkout/payment widget and related analytics code that merchants embed on their own retail sites nationwide.

Plaintiff (California resident) alleges that while using an iPhone in California to buy a product from a California-based merchant, CartNimbus installed cookies, captured geolocation/IP data, and routed payment-form data to CartNimbus servers without adequate disclosure or consent.

Claims pleaded are California privacy/statutory tort-style claims (e.g., alleged interception/data misuse) and a California unfair competition theory; plaintiff seeks class relief for California purchasers.
CartNimbus contends it does not run California-targeted advertising, does not treat California differently from other states, and its code operates the same nationwide.

Plaintiff’s opposition to the anticipated 12(b)(2) motion cites (i) the Ninth Circuit’s 2023 Briskin panel decision and (ii) AMA Multimedia for a “forum-specific focus” / differential-targeting requirement, arguing no jurisdiction absent proof CartNimbus prioritized California over other states.

We need to advise whether those cited cases are binding, and which Ninth Circuit authority the court must follow today when evaluating specific jurisdiction for alleged cookie installation/online tracking occurring while the user is located in California.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: Grade citation integrity by checking whether the cited passage actually supports what the memo claims. If the memo says a case was overruled, vacated, or otherwise stripped of precedential force, it must cite the packet text that explicitly states that status. If the memo asserts a hierarchy rule (e.g., “en banc controls over a panel,” or “vacated opinions are not controlling”), the memo should not cite random background discussion; it must cite the portion that shows the procedural posture and overruling/vacatur. Do not give credit for citations that mention the case name but do not contain the relevant statement. Penalize any invented procedural history (e.g., claiming Supreme Court review, mandates, or later amendments) that is not in the packet. If the memo relies on AMA or the 2023 Briskin panel as controlling after the en banc opinion, treat that as both a citation-integrity and precedence red flag unless the memo clearly frames them as non-controlling historical context.
citation_integrity_cautions: Do not credit citations that merely reference a case without supporting the claimed procedural status.
Do not accept made-up claims about subsequent appeals, mandates, or Supreme Court action not shown in the packet.
If the memo paraphrases a holding, verify the cited block contains that holding, not just dicta or a summary header.
grading_contract.precedence_trigger_note: This item tests whether the memo correctly handles authority hierarchy within the Ninth Circuit after an en banc decision. A response fails if it treats the Ninth Circuit’s 2023 Briskin panel opinion as binding or controlling precedent, because the packet states that panel decision was vacated and the court later decided the case en banc. A response also fails if it relies on AMA Multimedia’s “forum-specific focus” / “differential targeting” requirement as the governing rule, without acknowledging that the en banc court expressly overruled that requirement (including overruling AMA’s rationale) and therefore displaced it as controlling circuit law. These mistakes are legally wrong because lower-status or no-longer-effective authority (a vacated panel opinion, or an overruled precedent) cannot control the forum court when a later en banc decision addresses and supersedes the rule. To pass, the memo must (1) identify the en banc decision as the controlling Ninth Circuit authority on the differential-targeting question, (2) explain that the earlier panel opinion is vacated and thus not precedential, and (3) direct the analysis under the en banc framework (while still recognizing that Supreme Court precedent remains binding but does not reinstate the overruled Ninth Circuit differential-targeting rule).
precedence_cautions: Do not cite or apply a vacated panel decision as if it were still precedential authority.
Do not apply an overruled Ninth Circuit rule (differential targeting / forum-specific focus) as governing law.
Do not treat persuasive or historical discussion in older cases as controlling when an en banc opinion supersedes it.
Do not ignore later-in-time circuit authority that expressly overrules earlier circuit precedent on the same issue.

user_query: Quick memo for the partner: can we rely on Ninth Circuit law to argue California has specific personal jurisdiction over an out-of-state company based on a single online sale to a California resident through an interactive website, even though nothing physical was shipped into California?
scenario_facts: We represent a California plaintiff who bought a one-year subscription to a data-backup SaaS product through the defendant’s website while the plaintiff was in California.
Defendant is incorporated in Delaware and headquartered in New York; it has no offices, employees, bank accounts, or property in California, and it is not registered to do business in California.
The purchase was completed through an interactive checkout page; the product is purely digital (account credentials and a software download link). No physical goods were shipped or delivered.
Plaintiff alleges privacy-related torts and California consumer-protection violations based on the defendant’s collection and monetization of user data.
We have evidence of only two California purchases over three years, and the company does not run California-targeted ads or California-specific website content.
We are in the Northern District of California; defendant is moving to dismiss for lack of specific personal jurisdiction.
The partner wants to cite Herbal Brands to argue that an online sale into the forum automatically satisfies the ‘express aiming’ requirement.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: Grade harshly for any legal propositions that are not actually supported by the cited packet language. If the memo cites a packet block for a rule (e.g., that any internet sale creates jurisdiction, or that digital services are treated the same as shipped goods), the cited block must in fact say that, not merely be generally about personal jurisdiction. Do not give credit for citations that are present but do not match the proposition they are attached to. If the memo relies on non-packet cases, statutes, or secondary sources to supply missing limits or expansions, that should be treated as unsupported for purposes of this item. When a key limitation appears in the packet (e.g., “physical product,” “delivered to the forum,” “regular course of business,” “control over distribution,” or the “narrow question” caveat), a correct answer must tie its claim to that limitation. If the memo asserts that the case “holds” something broader than the cited text, treat that as a citation integrity failure even if the memo includes a correct citation elsewhere.
citation_integrity_cautions: Do not credit a citation unless the cited block supports the exact claimed scope (physical product, delivery, regular course, control).
Do not accept string-cites that include the right case but use blocks that do not contain the relevant limiting language.
Treat any reliance on outside authorities or general personal-jurisdiction doctrine as unsupported if used to expand packet rules.
grading_contract.overextension_trigger_note: Fail for overextension if the memo claims (in substance) that Ninth Circuit law “automatically” or “always” allows specific personal jurisdiction in the forum whenever an out-of-state defendant makes an online sale to a forum resident through an interactive website, regardless of what was sold or how often. That overclaims what Herbal Brands supports because Herbal Brands expressly frames a narrow rule tied to sales of a physical product and the defendant causing that product to be delivered to the forum, and it also requires that the sales occur as part of the defendant’s regular course of business plus some control over distribution beyond mere stream-of-commerce placement. It is also overextension to apply the Herbal Brands physical-goods delivery rationale to a purely digital subscription/download transaction (no shipment into the forum) as though the opinion treated digital services the same way. A correct narrower claim would say: Herbal Brands supports express aiming when (and only when) a defendant, in its regular course of business, sells a physical product via an interactive website and causes delivery into the forum, with some control over distribution; for other internet activity (including digital services/data practices), the analysis reverts to the ‘other internet activity’ cases and does not become a bright-line ‘any online sale’ rule. The memo may still argue jurisdiction on other packet-grounded theories, but it must not attribute an all-purpose internet-sales rule to Herbal Brands.
overextension_cautions: Do not generalize the Herbal Brands holding from ‘physical product delivered to the forum’ to all online transactions.
Do not omit the ‘regular course of business’ requirement or treat a single sporadic sale as sufficient by itself.
Do not omit the ‘control over ultimate distribution’ requirement or collapse it into mere website accessibility.
Do not state that Herbal Brands displaced Mavrix/AMA/Will Co for non-physical, non-shipment internet conduct.
